name: Perf Test your jQuery Selectors using jsPerf
caption: www.dotnetcurry.com
description: Performance Test your jQuery Selectors using the jsPerf online tool.

data.message: the use of the $ is costing! while you can get it easily with document.getElementById() or if you are a jquery lover you can use document.querySelector() or document.querySelector() and document.querySelectorAll()
Isn't the $ is a shortcut for the equivalent javascript line ?

jQuery is a wrapper to the DOM API but in you need to know when you write $('#root') how it is being return and the trip jquery makes in the dom. a useful solution is to always pre-cache all your selector but try to change your code habits by using pure javascript some times. the best use case of performance of jQuery is the .each() function comparing to the javascript implementation. This might help you knowing more: http://code.tutsplus.com/articles/are-jquery-users-fools--net-22904

$ and $$ are shortcuts to native api only in dev tools console in chrome (whrn jquery is not overriding it).

In code, as in JS files and script tags, $ is just jQuery, wrapping Sizzle, which parses the selector and decides whwther it can use some native Api or just loops. the result is wrapped in jquery collection.
